title: The ke'a Pronoun
goal: Learn to use `ke'a` for back-reference in relative clauses.

sections.content:
Warm-up (2-3 min)

poi review:

The dog which is blue → ?
The person who works → ?

(Answers: lo gerku poi blanu, lo prenu poi gunka)

New Material (5-7 min)

New Vocabulary

Lojban Place Structure English
pixra x1 is a picture of x2 made by x3 picture
sanga x1 sings x2 (song) sing

What Is ke'a?

ke'a refers back to the thing being described by the relative clause.

When Is ke'a Needed?

When the described thing is NOT x1 of the relative clause bridi:

lo prenu poi mi prami ke'a

The person whom I love.

Here, "person" is x2 of prami, not x1. So we need ke'a.

Default: ke'a is x1

When omitted, ke'a is assumed to be x1:

lo prenu poi tavla mi = lo prenu poi ke'a tavla mi

The person who talks to me.

Examples

lo cukta poi mi tcidu ke'a

The book which I read.

lo prenu poi mi prami ke'a cu melbi

The person whom I love is beautiful.

lo zdani poi mi xabju ke'a

The house which I live in.

Key Point

Use ke'a when the described thing is not x1 of the relative clause.
sections.title: New Material (5-7 min)

sections.content:
Practice (4-5 min)

Exercise 1: Use ke'a

Translate (described thing is not x1):

  1. The book which I read → ?
  2. The person whom I love → ?
  3. The house where I live → ?
Answers
  1. lo cukta poi mi tcidu ke'a
  2. lo prenu poi mi prami ke'a
  3. lo zdani poi mi xabju ke'a

Exercise 2: ke'a Optional

These don't need explicit ke'a (it's x1). Translate:

  1. The dog which barks → ?
  2. The person who goes → ?
  3. The singer who sings → ?
Answers
  1. lo gerku poi bacru (or appropriate verb)
  2. lo prenu poi klama
  3. lo sanga poi sanga (redundant but grammatical)

Exercise 3: New Vocabulary

Translate:

  1. This is a picture.
  2. I sing.
  3. The picture which I see is beautiful.
Answers
  1. ti pixra
  2. mi sanga
  3. lo pixra poi mi viska ke'a cu melbi

items.text: The picture which I see is beautiful.
items.answer: `lo pixra poi mi viska ke'a cu melbi`

sections.content:
Conversation Challenge (1-2 min)

Say aloud:

  1. "The book I read" → lo cukta poi mi tcidu ke'a
  2. "The person I love" → lo prenu poi mi prami ke'a
  3. "I sing." → mi sanga

Summary

You learned ke'a for back-reference. Use it when the described thing is not x1 of the relative clause.
